A competent CRPG of the golden era ported to the modern mobile century. 4.5/5 stars for me. Initially I had a hard time getting used to the touch controls to play it on my 10.5 inch Samsung A tablet. The main issue is with the camera panning control... it should be reversed IMO. But once I got used to it, the game itself is almost as good as the original can expect to be played on a mobile platform. The game can be taxing for low-end devices. My mid-range Samsung A stutters in places where there are a lot of enemies on screen and this game should definitely be played on at least a 7~8 inch phone/tablet. Anything smaller I imagine you'll have a hard time managing the inventory menus. It is absolutely worth the money. It's a lot of original content for what it's asking. Nothing is "randomly-generated" and it delivers a good story line. It's great to re-experience NWN again, just like all the Baldur's Gate I&II/IWD/Planescape Torment I bought. I even tried it on Bluestack and it works on desktop PC!

content: Your father's RPG. This is the game of a D&D player. Not as clumsy or as random as a free-to-play clicker. An elegant RPG... for a more civilized age. Recommend you play this on a high-powered chromebook or tablet with a keyboard. The keyboard shortcuts are what really makes the game playable. This game may seem a bit complex when you first start. Here are some tips for newcomers: * Learn all the keyboard shortcuts. Especially the 'space' key to pause the game. Any time you are about to get into combat, hit the space key to buy yourself some time to queue up your actions. Also the 'G' key is your friend. Quicksave often, especially before you open a door into an unknown area... * Use the standard camera follow mode. This setup has the camera sort of float behind your character. Get used to moving around with the WASD keys. If you need to zoom in and out you can use the arrows. You should rarely need to control the camera manually in this mode. I mapped the . and / keys to the 'raise' and 'lower' camera actions. This is because the Pixelbook doesn't have easily accessible F1-F12 or pgup/pgdown keys. * If your chromebook has a touchpad (or external mouse) you can access most of the options for anything by long-clicking on it. This is one of the great things about this game. You can do actions from almost anywhere using the radial menus. Take some time to go through each option for your items and understand what they all do. * Sometimes the doors between areas will get a bit buggy. Back up and go through the door again and it will work. Also, if your keyboard controls stop working, ALT-TAB to another application (like Chrome), and back into the game. This seems to reset the inputs. * Often your character or henchman will be in the way while you're trying to click on a chest or bag. Use the Q and E keys to sidestep away from the chest before you click on it. * Load up your quickbar with the actions and weapons you use the most. You can put two weapons or a weapon and a shield into the same quickbar spot, for quick access. The game has 50-60 hours of content for you to enjoy. If you are a fan of Dungeons and Dragons or computer RPGs, or both, this is a must have for your Chromebook or high-end Android tablet. Easily worth several times the price you pay for the game.

content: Good port, as long as you understand it IS a port. There are issues to be aware of. First, controls are not as easy as made out. Rotating the camera is tedious, and more often than not results in you moving the character unintentionally. Same with zoom. At least on my Pixel C, rotating by swiping the screen edge rarely works. Instead try swiping close to the character. Second, taps sometimes take two or more taps to execute commands (opening chests, collecting loot, or even just moving). Probably because the game is originally designed for a mouse and not my fat fingers. There are other minor issues as well, but if you can get used to the quirks it is a fun game. The only real issue I have is with the Pixel C keyboard the game crashes on the save dialog and if the keyboard is disconnected, so I would advise those users just remove it or disable bluetooth before playing.
